description: Recorded since 1297 as Middle English caucioun (“bail, guarantee, pledge”), from Old French caution (“security, surety”), itself from Latin cautiō, from cautus, past participle of caveō, cavēre (“be on one's guard”).

entries.meaning: Prudence when faced with, or when expecting to face, danger; care taken in order to avoid risk or harm.
examples: utmost caution is required when travelling in this dangerous neighbourhood

entries.meaning: A careful attention to the probable effects of an act, in order that failure or harm may be avoided.
examples: The guideline expressed caution against excessive radiographic imaging.

entries.meaning: (dated) One who draws attention or causes astonishment by their behaviour.
examples: Oh, that boy, he's a caution! He does make me laugh.

entries.meaning: (law) A formal warning given as an alternative to prosecution in minor cases.

verbs.description: caution (third-person singular simple present cautions, present participle cautioning, simple past and past participle cautioned)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To warn; to alert, advise that caution is warranted.
